t: Job 20
Zophar Speaks: The Wicked Will Suffer
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
“Therefore*pn my thoughts answer me, because*ld of my haste within me.
I*ln hear censure that insults me, and*ld out of my understanding a spirit answers me.
Do*ln you not know this from of old, since*ld man was placed on earth,
that*ln the exulting of the wicked is short, and*ld the joy of the godless but for a moment?
Though*ln his height mount up to the heavens, and*ld his head reach to the clouds,
he*ln will perish forever like his own dung; those*ld who have seen him will say, ‘Where is he?’
He*ln will fly away like a dream and not be found; he*ld will be chased away like a vision of the night.
The*ln eye that saw him will see him no more, nor*ld will his place any more behold him.
His*ln children will seek the favor of the poor, and*ld his hands will give back his wealth.
His*ln bones are full of his youthful vigor, but*ld it will lie down with him in the dust.
“Though*pn evil is sweet in his mouth, though*ld he hides it under his tongue,
though*ln he is loath to let it go and*ld holds it in his mouth,
yet*ln his food is turned in his stomach; it*ld is the venom of cobras within him.
He*ln swallows down riches and vomits them up again; God*ld casts them out of his belly.
He*ln will suck the poison of cobras; the*ld tongue of a viper will kill him.
He*ln will not look upon the rivers, the*ld streams flowing with honey and curds.
He*ln will give back the fruit of his toil and*ld will not swallow it down; from*ln the profit of his trading he*ld will get no enjoyment.
For*ln he has crushed and abandoned the poor; he*ld has seized a house that he did not build.
“Because*pn he knew no contentment in his belly, he*ld will not let anything in which he delights escape him.
There*ln was nothing left after he had eaten; therefore*ld his prosperity will not endure.
In*ln the fullness of his sufficiency he will be in distress; the*ld hand of everyone in misery will come against him.
To*ln fill his belly to the full, God*ld will send his burning anger against him and*ld rain it upon him into his body.
He*ln will flee from an iron weapon; a*ld bronze arrow will strike him through.
It*ln is drawn forth and comes out of his body; the*ld glittering point comes out of his gallbladder; terrors*ld come upon him.
Utter*ln darkness is laid up for his treasures; a*ld fire not fanned will devour him; what*ld is left in his tent will be consumed.
The*ln heavens will reveal his iniquity, and*ld the earth will rise up against him.
The*ln possessions of his house will be carried away, dragged*ld off in the day of God’s wrath.
This*ln is the wicked man’s portion from God, the*ld heritage decreed for him by God.”
